name: Kristin Kumm Connon
description: Writer. AKA Special K. CEO at Connon Trucking LLC.  Aspie. Bookkeeper. ASL student. Friend, wife, mom + more! #OMD ğŸ’‹ğŸ‘ŠğŸ¤Ÿ
tweet: Ok, serious tip. After making sure the hair and rods are THOROUGHLY rinsed, blot hair and carefully, oh so gently, wind your hair again and allow to air dry. I only use about half the rods this time, but it makes my perm last longer and reduces post-perm frizz.

name: Kristin Kumm Connon
description: Writer. AKA Special K. CEO at Connon Trucking LLC.  Aspie. Bookkeeper. ASL student. Friend, wife, mom + more! #OMD ğŸ’‹ğŸ‘ŠğŸ¤Ÿ
tweet: Remove the rods as you rinse the neutralizer. I usually pray to the altar of @bradmondonyc at this point, hoping to all that is fabulous (aka, him) that my hair doesn't fall out in chunks at this step.

name: Kristin Kumm Connon
description: Writer. AKA Special K. CEO at Connon Trucking LLC.  Aspie. Bookkeeper. ASL student. Friend, wife, mom + more! #OMD ğŸ’‹ğŸ‘ŠğŸ¤Ÿ
tweet: Now it's time for the neutralizing cream. Fun fact! While it sounds all wholesome, bringing images of the friendly Swiss to mind, this is actually the WORST PART FOR YOUR HAIR. Time carefully. Also, it is not actually a cream and does drip, so more cotton and Rambo impressions. https://t.co/6dtPc2Ql20

name: Kristin Kumm Connon
description: Writer. AKA Special K. CEO at Connon Trucking LLC.  Aspie. Bookkeeper. ASL student. Friend, wife, mom + more! #OMD ğŸ’‹ğŸ‘ŠğŸ¤Ÿ
tweet:
My dear children,
I see you running
Racing toward 
That sunrise of adulthood. 
Please slow down. 
That day is long
And ends in twilight. 
Enjoy the dawn
And lock the stars in your eyes
So you always remember 
This magic 
This feeling
Of possibility. 
#amwriting #poetry
#freeverse

description: Writer. AKA Special K. CEO at Connon Trucking LLC.  Aspie. Bookkeeper. ASL student. Friend, wife, mom + more! #OMD ğŸ’‹ğŸ‘ŠğŸ¤Ÿ
tweet:
"But, you seem normal. Like, you don't ACT autistic."

I wish I had 
An once of self esteem 
For every time I've heard this.
I would be:
Unafraid. 
Unashamed.
Uncovered.
Unbroken. 
Your compliments hurt.
Please stop.
So I can stop pretending. 
#Poetry #freeverse #ActuallyAutistic

name: Kristin Kumm Connon
description: Writer. AKA Special K. CEO at Connon Trucking LLC.  Aspie. Bookkeeper. ASL student. Friend, wife, mom + more! #OMD ğŸ’‹ğŸ‘ŠğŸ¤Ÿ
tweet: @BrookeJSauthor Maybe think of it as God/god? Are you talking about a general god or one specific God i.e. God of the Christian faith? In your case it really sounds like you can play the rules a little loose.

name: Kristin Kumm Connon
description: Writer. AKA Special K. CEO at Connon Trucking LLC.  Aspie. Bookkeeper. ASL student. Friend, wife, mom + more! #OMD ğŸ’‹ğŸ‘ŠğŸ¤Ÿ
tweet: @BrookeJSauthor You can get away with either, I'd think. Depending on your books culture setup. If it's an honorific, you can choose to capitalize. A mention in passing? Lowercase. Ex: "I saw the assassin run from the scene of the murder" vs. "I invited The Assassin to dinner."

name: Kristin Kumm Connon
description: Writer. AKA Special K. CEO at Connon Trucking LLC.  Aspie. Bookkeeper. ASL student. Friend, wife, mom + more! #OMD ğŸ’‹ğŸ‘ŠğŸ¤Ÿ
tweet: @BrookeJSauthor Those are only proper nouns if cultural expectations make them so. You can get away with capitalizing it if that's the culture of your world in the story. I wouldn't capitalize "the president" in general or even "my president" but I would "Mr. President"

name: Kristin Kumm Connon

tweet: @BrookeJSauthor But if we just don't know his name, and that is what he is referred to, still lowercase "the boy" rule.

name: Kristin Kumm Connon
description: Writer. AKA Special K. CEO at Connon Trucking LLC.  Aspie. Bookkeeper. ASL student. Friend, wife, mom + more! #OMD ğŸ’‹ğŸ‘ŠğŸ¤Ÿ
tweet: @laney_lam That's the scariest part of being a teen: that feeling of isolation. Feeling like no one else understands the stuff you have to put up with. A lot of young people feel that way. I certainly did. I know better now, but at the time it was terrifying.

name: Kristin Kumm Connon
description: Writer. AKA Special K. CEO at Connon Trucking LLC.  Aspie. Bookkeeper. ASL student. Friend, wife, mom + more! #OMD ğŸ’‹ğŸ‘ŠğŸ¤Ÿ
tweet: I hope everyone is enjoying the polls and I love how many votes they get. I want to point out that I don't think any writer uses bad character tropes on purpose. Like everything else, it's part of learning. I try to learn from my mistakes and the mistakes of others. #amwriting

tweet: @laney_lam I think my biggest challenge is accurately portraying that feeling of being stuck between childhood and adulthood. I had some pretty messed up teenage years though. Lol

name: Kristin Kumm Connon
description: Writer. AKA Special K. CEO at Connon Trucking LLC.  Aspie. Bookkeeper. ASL student. Friend, wife, mom + more! #OMD ğŸ’‹ğŸ‘ŠğŸ¤Ÿ
tweet: @AnnMalleyBooks The classics are brilliant! But there are many contemporary wonders people can miss if we assign them to some elite class. I know a woman who refuses to read anything by a living author and scoffs at me for reading Atwood. It's sad! Just read, people!!! It's all wonderful!!

name: Kristin Kumm Connon
description: Writer. AKA Special K. CEO at Connon Trucking LLC.  Aspie. Bookkeeper. ASL student. Friend, wife, mom + more! #OMD ğŸ’‹ğŸ‘ŠğŸ¤Ÿ
tweet: @AnnMalleyBooks And I made the same mistake when I was younger. I thought I was just oh-so-special because I binged on Hemmingway, Dickens, Austen, and Fitzgerald. I'm not any more special than readers and writers who prefer contemporary works. They are tomorrow's classics.

name: Kristin Kumm Connon
description: Writer. AKA Special K. CEO at Connon Trucking LLC.  Aspie. Bookkeeper. ASL student. Friend, wife, mom + more! #OMD ğŸ’‹ğŸ‘ŠğŸ¤Ÿ
tweet: @AnnMalleyBooks Allow me to clarify: I don't mean mentions of reading them, I mean people that use the information to imply they are in some way superior to those that haven't read them, usually with the assumption that most other people have not read them. It's strange to me how often I see it.

tweet: @NeilElfberg I like to write things that challenge what I think I know. I was surprised by how much I had trouble keeping pronouns correct for my own trans character. I had fancied myself good at that sort of thing. I know the LGBTQ community, but I still have more to learn!

tweet: The last choice has taken a sizable lead! It seems we dislike mansplaining. To me the worst part is the 'splainer is blithely unaware that other the people are not, in fact, actually stupid. I think this as an honest character representation reveals a lot about an author.
